title: Lent celebrations in Saraburi
text:
NEWSPAPER SECTION: LIFE | WRITER: PICHAYA SVASTI - + From July 29-31, Wat Phra Phutthabat in Saraburi will host the "Tak Bat Dok Mai" (floral merit-making) ceremony to mark Khao Phansa Day, the start of Buddhist Lent. 
Merit-making at Wat Phra Phutthabat. 
On the first day, the opening ceremony will begin at 5pm. Activities will include worshipping the spirit of King Song Tham, who established the temple during the Ayutthaya period, and the holy spirits around the temple, the simulation of King Song Tham's royal barge procession, local performances and flower parades. 
For every day until the third day, which is the start of Lent, there will be two ceremonies a day for Buddhists to present yellow, white or purple flowers called dok khao phansa (Buddhist Lent flowers) to monks who are climbing the temple's stairs to worship the Buddha's footprint. They will also wash the monks' feet as a symbol of clearing away bad deeds. Call the Tourism Authority of Thailand's Lop Buri office on 036-770-096/7. Yai Dok Mai in Sing Buri 
From July 30-31, Wat Chinda Manee in Sing Buri's Phrom Buri district will host a floral merit-making ceremony called "Yai Dok Mai". 
The tradition has been carried on for more than a century by locals whose ancestors were from Vientiane in Laos. On the first day, there will be alms giving to monks in the morning and preparations of the next day's ceremonies. 
On Khao Phansa Day, a special kind of drum called klong chae will be hit for half-an-hour at the temple before locals arrive for floral alms-giving. 
On this long weekend, tourists can also visit Sing Buri's major temples like Wat Phra Non Chaksi, Wat Phikun Thong and Wat Prachotikaram as well as the statue of the Ban Bang Rachan heroes. Visit www.tat7.com or call the local TAT office on 036-770-096/7. Candle procession in Suphan Buri 
From July 30 to Aug 1, the annual Buddhist Lent Candle Procession will take place at various venues in Muang district, Suphan Buri province. 
On July 31, the opening ceremony will begin at 8am with the procession of lent candles from all 10 districts of Suphan Buri at the 1st highway office. In the procession, there will be local dances and parades. Also, there will be the lent candle making contests, the display of candles and cultural performances to celebrate the festival at Wat Pa Lelai in Muang district. Those who click Like on the Facebook page of the event will receive gift. Visit www.tatsuphan.net or call the local TAT office on 035-525-867. Family rally to Kanchanaburi 
On Aug 8, the TAT's Kanchanaburi office will host the "Fun Travel to the Eastern Paradise" rally from Siam Niramit show venue near Ratchadaphisek Road to Kanchanaburi province. 
The objectives are to promote local tourist attractions, enhance love among family members and highlight this province's uniqueness in terms of historical and natural tourism in August, which is the month of family happiness as designated by the TAT. 
On the route, the first destination is Wat Phrathaen Dong Rang which has a large stone panel simulating the place in India where the Lord Buddha left this world and attained nirvana. 
Next, participants will have lunch and enjoy a tram ride at the Safari Park and Resort open zoo. 
All will reach the finish point at the Lake Heaven Resort near the Sri Nakharin Dam where they will enjoy a dinner party with fun games, lucky draws and an awards presentation. 
On Aug 9, they can spend time in the resort swimming and playing water sports before going home or travelling further in Kanchanaburi. The fee is 5,299 baht per two persons per room (free admission for children under four). Email the organiser at gps.kongton @gmail.com or call Khun Orn on 081-555-8741 or Khun Chote on 081-753-8280.
